body:
Can you elaborate a bit more? Do you have any concerns?

On Tue, Dec 22, 2015 at 9:40 PM, Yunseong Lee notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @bgchun https://github.com/bgchun @afchung https://github.com/afchung
> I resolved the merge conflicts.
> With changes in #738 https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/738, Tasklet
> does not handle the result anymore; the result is passed by
> VortexFutureDelegate instead. So I added OutputCodec in VortexFuture
> where the result is the passed to user at the last moment. Could you please
> take a look and let me know if there would be a better solution? Thanks!
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/739#issuecomment-166608158.

## 

Byung-Gon Chun

@bgchun Actually, this is not very different from the previous one: the result is passed as a serialized byte[], and it is decoded when the result comes out. One thing I'd like to make sure is this PR does not conflict with the changes that @afchung would make.

@yunseong I think it should be fine. It would be ideal if we could make the constructor of `VortexFuture` private and Injected, or at least package-private, although I don't think TANG is able to Inject generics.

However, a potential problem I see here is that the Tasklet will be in an "uncertain" state if deserialization fails on `completed`. Should `threwException` be invoked in this case? Because although the Tasklet succeeded in execution, the user is unable to fetch the results.
Looks good, I will test and merge.
This looks good, will merge.

@afchung Thanks for the comment. I totally agree with you. Then throwing an explicit exception (e.g., `SerializationException`) instead of `RuntimeException`, and invoking `threwException` would be more proper way. I'll give it a try and let you know when it's ready.

As `Codec`(https://reef.apache.org/apidocs/0.13.0-incubating/org/apache/reef/io/serialization/Codec.html) does not throw exception explicitly, 
it is hard to handle the failure during serialization. Following are possible solutions I've thought:
1. Avoid using REEF's Codec and define our own codec which throws Exceptions. This is simple, but we have another interface with same function, which REEF already has two (one in `o.a.r.io.serialization`, and the other in `o.a.r.wake.remote`).
2. Make users throw an Exception which extends RuntimeException(e.g., `SerializationException`), and handle the specific exception when (de-)serializing fails. For this, users should throw the specific exception.
3. Modify Codec to throw Exceptions explicitly. But this brings some changes in `reef.io` part, so I think it'd be good to discuss via `dev` mailing list first.

@bgchun @afchung How do you think? Any better solution to suggest?
@yunseong as a quick solution, the easiest thing to do may just be to catch all `Exceptions`, wrap the Exception in a `SerializationException`, and pass it to `threwException`.

@afchung Thanks for the suggestion. But catching general Exception is what we'd like to avoid (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-864).

As the codec throws RuntimeException internally, the job fails when serialization has failed. For explicit exception handling,  what about adding an issue and leaving TODO comment here?
I see, can you open a JIRA for that and link it to this one such that we'll know to come back later? Thanks!
I think this can be merged otherwise.
@afchung Thanks for the confirmation! I filed a JIRA (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1114) and add `TODO` comments. @bgchun Do you have other comments? Thanks!
I'll test and merge after @bgchun signs off.
@afchung @yunseong Looks good. I sign off.
@bgchun @afchung Thanks a lot!
Looks good. I've fixed a bunch more typos, in wrong punctuation and capitalization, rather than pointing them out for a new iteration. Will merge.
Oh, thank you, @tcNickolas .
Looks good, I'll merge
Oops, I've forgotten to add PR # to commit message. Could you please close PR manually?
Sure. No problem. Ur, by the way, it seems to be merged and closed.

@tcNickolas , it looks much more natural and I think it's desirable behavior in GitHub.
Should we omit the specific PR number from now?
We can discuss on dev list. Cons is, we don't have PR # in commit message anymore, so it takes one step longer to get to PR from commit (have to go via JIRA issue)
Oh, I forgot that cons. Then, let's keep the current way. I prefer direct access, too. Thank you for pointing out that.
@markusweimer anymore comments?
I will test and merge.
@jwang98052 I've done another pass.
I will test and merge.
I will test and merge.

Addressed review comments and pushed in. 
@markusweimer see my comments regarding the file name and let me know your opinion.
Do we need to increase the size of the images? I'm not sure how github resizes them when displaying README.md, they might not scale.
Looks good, I'll merge

You can see that on my PR branch.

https://github.com/dongjoon-hyun/reef/tree/REEF-1115/lang/java/reef-tang
Hi, @tcNickolas . I closed old two PRs and create a new one for REEF-989. I will update Wiki, too.

Here is the diff of Wiki page.

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/diffpagesbyversion.action?pageId=51806300&selectedPageVersions=23&selectedPageVersions=22

Thank you all of your help.

Larger images scale fine.
Is Comic Sans (if I identify the font in the images correctly) a good choice for documentation?

> Is Comic Sans (if I identify the font in the images correctly) a good choice for documentation?

Well, it is fun :-) But more seriously speaking, Helvetica or such would be more appropriate.

It's just due to the following `Tang Tint`'s current logic. Do you want to change that into `Helvetica` in this issue? No problem to do that. :)

```
out.println("body { font-family: 'Segoe UI', 'Comic Sans MS'; font-size:12pt; font-weight: 200; " +
            "margin: 1em; column-count: 2; }");
```
This PR except the one thing, `iAmAClass`, looks good to me.
@markusweimer have addressed review comments and pushed in. Thanks!
I'll test and merge.
I think we can merge this PR without any changes since we've waited more opinions for a while. I'll test and merge this.

Should we also have a script to change year in all places it is used at, similar to a script to change version? It will, of course, be used approximately 18 times less often (assuming 6 releases per year, 3 change_version per release). But it would also serve as a reminder to update the year.

Yes, I think it would be better to change the font to something more serious. After all, we've graduated from the incubator already ;-)

Also, the font in the code screenshot looks a bit weird too; could you make it something monospaced, like the font used in the previous version of the screenshot?

I totally agree with you. But I'm not good at this kind of art or designing work. 
Could you choose the font name specifically for me? :)

I added that missing file to `change_version.py`, too.

For the new script, +1 for the idea. But, I'm not interested at making `change_year.py` by myself in this PR. If needed, we can make a simple task JIRA for that. :-)
What is the proper format for copyright dates? In NOTICE you're using 2015-2016, while in assembly info you're using 2016 only. Is there any reference document for when to use which?

Yep, here for `NOTICE` file, http://www.apache.org/legal/src-headers.html#notice .

```
The top of each NOTICE file should include the following text, suitably modified to reflect the product 
name and year(s) of distribution of the current and past versions of the product:
```

For the `AssemblyCopyright`, I thought it should be consistent with the release date in NuGet stuff.
I'll merge this
Thank you, @tcNickolas .
As Marcus suggested, Helvetica for Tint-generated page. For tooltip screenshot, whichever monospaced font your IDE has (mine has just "Monospaced" as a default, but it's not a font name)

For 'Tint' code, I will change the following line into `Helvetica` instead of `Comic Sans` as you specified.

```
out.println("body { font-family: 'Segoe UI', 'Comic Sans MS'; font-size:12pt; font-weight: 200; " +
            "margin: 1em; column-count: 2; }");
```

But, for tooltip screen, what is your IDE and what OS do you mean? I didn't change any of the default setting of `Eclipse IDE (Mars.1 Release 4.5.1)`. In fact, I installed Eclipse on my Mac just to capture this tooltip image since the original image came from Eclipse.

I can capture that after newly installing Eclipse IDE on Windows 10. Do you think that is okay for you? I'm not sure what font will be, but I guess it will be closer to your environment.

Fonts or designs are always controversial. I didn't expect that I need to change the existing font of `Tint` code. :)
I'm still working on this. I'll let you know later.
@tcNickolas . It looks good to me. I'll test and merge this.
@markusweimer or @afchung, could you please take a look? This seems related to https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/580, as it mostly deprecates constants used in methods deprecated in it.
@tcNickolas looks good to me.
Looks good, I'll merge
Thank you, @tcNickolas !

Is there a specific advantage to using `getCause()` in places where exception from the check is configured? Might it be simpler to just use the exception we catch, if it produces full stack trace? In REEF-864 you mentioned `getRootCause()` which goes all the way to the root cause, not just one level up
@bgchun @yunseong @johnyangk this is still a bit rough around the edges, but please have a look. Thanks!
Thanks @afchung I'll take a look.

> Is there a specific advantage to using getCause() in places where exception from the check is configured?

I think no, but I left the code with  `getCause()` intact to avoid changing error handling in the clients of this code. Also, the `getCause()` seems necessary in certain cases like  this `IOException` to `ParseException` conversion in `CommandLine.java`

> In REEF-864 you mentioned getRootCause() which goes all the way to the root cause, not just one level up

REEF has  the equivalent `getUltimateCause()` in `Exceptions.java`

@afchung This looks great, and your kind explanation in #738 helped me understand this code. 
I left some comments and questions. Could you please take a look? Thanks!
@yunseong I've replied to some of your comments regarding the more open questions, please let me know what you think. I'll fix some of the obvious things first. Thanks for the review!
Looks good to me too, I'll test and merge.
@jwang98052 @dkm2110 Please have a look to make sure that I'm not accidentally hiding any APIs that are meant to be public. Thanks!
@jwang98052 @dkm2110 Can classes in O.A.R.Network/Group/Operators/Impl be made internal? I see that they're being used in our test code, but I'm not sure if they're meant to be hidden or not.
Looks good to me. I will test and merge.
@markusweimer, do you want to be the 3rd opinion on this change? :-)

The filter in the current PR seems to be fine to me. If I understand correctly, the risk is that we pick up an older version of the jar in a future test. That seems unlikely, as Maven keeps the `target` folder quite tidy. Also, the CI servers nuke that folder prior to building, so the only JAR there that matches is the one just created. I think we _should_ be fine with this.

That said, we do in fact have `org.apache.reef.util.REEFVersion` to look up the exact version of REEF if we wanted to.
@shulmanb @afchung What is the status of this? I believe this PR should be closed for now, right?
Then I think we should use `REEFVersion` to get exact names of jars without hardcoding them.

For classes in classes in O.A.R.Network/Group/Operators/Impl, if all the methods exposed in the classes are defined in the interface, then we can safely change the classes into internal. I looked it, it seems not always the  case. 
If tests only access interface methods, then we can change as well. 
Another way to look at it is to check if IMRU uses it or not as IMRU is an client example essentially. 

@dkm2110 please look at it as you use it more.
I completed my pass.
@markusweimer I am +1 for closing this PR.

@jwang98052 I've addressed your comments. On `GroupCommDriver`, I believe I may have set it as a default implementation to parallel `GroupCommClient`. Would you know if `GroupCommClient` should actually be set as a default implementation? Since it also has some named parameters to bind from the user.

I've done a surface level pass. Don't block on me in the merge, though.

`O.A.R.Network/Group/Operators/Impl` _should_ be all `internal`, but I am not 100% sure whether that is safe.

Thanks, @afchung 

@shulmanb, can you please go ahead and close it, then?

Will close it and create new Jira for further discussion.

-----Original Message-----
From: "Markus Weimer" notifications@github.com
Sent: â€Ž1/â€Ž14/â€Ž2016 1:26 PM
To: "apache/reef" reef@noreply.github.com
Cc: "Boris Shulman" shulmanb@gmail.com
Subject: Re: [reef] [REEF-1083] Implement OnCompleted for the wake remoteobservers (#734)

Thanks, @afchung 
@shulmanb, can you please go ahead and close it, then?
â€”
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

@markusweimer I've addressed your comments, please have another look. I also agree that `O.A.R.Network/Group/Operators/Impl` should be internal as well, but we don't have enough test cases to make sure that this is safe at the moment. Thanks!
Maybe we can mark all of those `impl` classes as `[Private]` then? That would give us license to make them `internal` in the next version.

Sounds like a plan. I see that `TreeTopology` and `FlatTopology` are instantiating some of these classes via injection. I'm assuming TreeTopology and FlatTopology are actually the classes that _should_ be exposed?
Yes, I believe `TreeTopology` and `FlatTopology` need to be `public`.
I've done a sruface-level pass. Overall looks good, but I left some minor nitpicks about unrelated changes and potential breakage of `public`, yet `[Unstable]` APIs.
Just a note, but I left all public generic classes as extendable classes.
The last commit looks good to me and addresses all comments. I'll test and merge this.

@afchung Thanks for addressing my comments.

Regarding input/function list (`getAggregatedInputAndFunction()`), you're right; `Tasklet` is not user-facing API, so user cannot get the information about input and function. Sorry for the confusion!

I have two questions:
- I think it's great to let users know input/function list for retrying if aggregation has failed. But wouldn't it be expensive to keep all the information, especially when input is very large? Of course, using large input for a single Tasklet does not fit Vortex well.
- We don't have the corresponding method in `VortexFuture` for Tasklet, right? I think it will be useful as well, but I'm not sure that calling `onSuccess` with the info is the best choice in both case.

@yunseong To simplify our error reporting for failed Tasklets on aggregation, I can think of a few other ways, but none of them are really great:
1. Only allow a single type of `VortexFunction`: Currently we allow aggregating different types of `VortexFunctions`. By allowing only a single type of `VortexFunction`, we only need to report the input of the failed `VortexFunction` to the user instead of an input-function pair. However, this also limits the type of work that the user can do.
2. Return the index of the failed input within the list of input-functions that the user supplies OR allow users to provide unique IDs for their input-function pair: This wouldn't really be helpful either, since the user will likely still need to keep the input-function pair locally to translate from index to input.
3. Allow the user to configure how to report the failed Tasklet: 3 levels -- no report (or fail, though this is not ideal), report input on failure, and report input-function pair on failure. If we want to go with this, I'll still need to think about how to code it up, but this gives users more control over what can be done.

Also, I'm a bit unclear about the second point of your question. Could you please clarify?

Finally, would you happen to know how mapreduce handles this situation? Perhaps we can gain some insight there. My understanding is that it only reports the task failure after the MR job is finished on the dashboard, but I could be wrong. Let me know what you think. Thanks!

@yunseong From http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11401678/an-unhandled-exception-in-mapper-or-reducer-task-would-make-the-task-failed, it would appear that MR allows "automatic" retries, but if a task repeatedly fails a certain amount of time, the job is marked as failed. Provided that Vortex is more general than MR, I would prefer to let the user handle the retry logic.
Looks good to me. Will test and merge after the nit. Thanks!
Ah, yes, Tang should not have a dependency on REEF. Only the other way around. Hence, I am +1 on merging the code as in this PR right now.
Thank you, @markusweimer .
Hi, @afchung . It looks good to me. I finished testing, too. I'll merge this.
Could you test on Mac or Linux, too?

Not for the next couple of hours :-(
I've also noticed that I forgot license, so here's new version with license and different direction of `/` in relative paths.

Is there any reason not to use the default Doxygen filename, `Doxyfile`? If not, please rename `doxygen.config` into the standard name, `Doxyfile`. And please remove all verbose comments in `doxygen.config`. I think `KEY=VALUE` pairs are enough for us.
